technical_features.source_sentence: The maximum adsorption capacity obtained from Langmuir fitting was equal to 146.28 mg P/g.
Our 1/n value obtained for phosphate adsorption by BC-5 was equal to 0.41.

The highest fitting accuracy was obtained when we fitted our adsorption data using the Sips model, which implies that phosphate adsorption on the BC-5 surface was a combination of mono- and multilayer adsorption.
The equilibrium adsorption capacity calculated from the pseudo-second-order kinetic equation was 87.55 mg P/g, which is very close to the value obtained experimentally (equal to 89.50 mg P/g).
The highest adsorption efficiency (equal to 93.33%) was achieved at pH = 11.
NO₃⁻ inhibited phosphate adsorption by the BC-5 material: the corresponding adsorption capacities decreased by 3.72%.
PO₄³⁻ was complexed by biochar’s Ca²⁺ yielding hydroxyapatite.

qualitative_insights.main_objective: Develop Ca-enriched biochar from sheep manure and oyster shells for efficient phosphate removal from wastewater
key_methodology_summary: Pyrolysis of sheep manure at 500°C under N₂ atmosphere
Chemical modification with oyster shell-derived Ca using HCl treatment
Characterization using SEM-EDS, FTIR, XRD, and BET surface analysis
primary_findings_conclusions: Maximum adsorption capacity of 146.28 mg P/g (Langmuir model)
94% removal efficiency at 50 mg P/L concentration
Adsorption mechanism dominated by Ca²⁺-PO₄³⁻ complexation forming hydroxyapatite
limitations_discussed_by_authors: Reduced surface area (4.74 m²/g) and pore volume after Ca modification compared to raw biochar
qualitative_insights.novelty_significance_claim: First use of oyster shell waste combined with livestock manure for sustainable adsorbent production
